title: PTC Therapeutics Vatiquinone Program Update for Friedreich's Ataxia â€“ January 21, 2025
description:
FARA's Mission is to marshal and focus the resources and relationships needed to cure Friedreich's Ataxia (FA) by raising funds for research, promoting public awareness, and aligning scientists, patients, clinicians, government agencies, pharmaceutical companies and other organizations dedicated to curing FA and related diseases.

Friedreichâ€™s Ataxia is a debilitating, life-shortening, degenerative neuro-muscular disorder. About one in 50,000 people in the United States have Friedreich's Ataxia.

This video is a recording of an informational webinar hosted by PTC Therapeutics on January 21, 2025. Chief Executive Officer of PTC Therapeutics, Matt Klein, M.D., M.S., F.A.C.S., joined FARA to discuss the vatiquinone program. Vatiquinone (PTC-743) is an investigational drug that aims to improve mitochondrial and cellular function by targeting 15-lipoxygenase. It is under evaluation and not approved by the FDA as of the date of this recording.  Information shared in this webinar is for educational purposes only and should not be construed as medical advice. FARA makes no representations regarding the information included in the recording. Those viewing the recording after January 21, 2025, are reminded that the field is constantly evolving, and the information contained in this recording may have changed. Anyone considering participating in a clinical trial should discuss the matter with their physician. FARA does not endorse or recommend any particular study.

title: Post 53 | Overcoming Communication Barriers with Large Language Models
description:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are revolutionizing communication for individuals with conditions like Friedreich's Ataxia. The key lies in their training on extensive linguistic datasets. These datasets provide the LLM with a rich understanding of syntax, morphology, and semantics. The benefits extend beyond simple translation. LLMs reduce the cognitive load associated with communication, allowing individuals to focus on the content of their message rather than the mechanics of speech. 
They also offer increased accessibility, providing a consistent and reliable communication tool that can be used in a variety of settings. Furthermore, these models can be integrated with various devices, offering flexible and adaptable solutions. We explore how the sophisticated linguistic processing within these models is enabling more effective and cohesive communication for Andrew Marshall and others, and how these benefits are transforming lives.
Key Benefits to Emphasize:
Increased Independence: LLMs empower individuals to communicate without constant reliance on others.
Reduced Frustration: Clearer communication minimizes misunderstandings and frustration.
Enhanced Social Inclusion: Improved communication facilitates meaningful social interactions.
Faster Communication: LLMs can process and generate responses quickly, improving communication efficiency.
Accuracy: LLMs can accurately interpret fragmented or altered speech.
Personalization: Models can be tailored to individual speech patterns.
Reduced Cognitive Load: LLMs handle the linguistic processing, allowing users to focus on their message.
Increased Accessibility: LLMs provide a reliable communication tool in various settings.
Adaptability: LLMs can be integrated with various devices and platforms.
Improved Quality of Life: Overall, LLMs contribute to a better quality of life by facilitating effective communication.

title: Friedreich's Ataxia (FA) What is this rare disease? A new chapter for us!
description:
Friedreich's ataxia (FA) is a rare, inherited disease that causes progressive damage to the nervous system: 

Symptoms usually begin between the ages of 5 and 15, but can appear later in life: 
Impaired muscle coordination (ataxia) 
Difficulty walking 
Poor balance 
Loss of sensation in the arms and legs 
Slowed speech 
Hearing loss 
Vision loss 
Scoliosis (curvature of the spine) 
Heart disease, such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 
Diabetes.

Prognosis.. Most patients die within ten to 20 years after being diagnosed. Some die much sooner, as each individuals body progresses at different levels. There is NO known cure and the life of a person with this disease will be incredibly challenging!

title: Ask the Ataxia Expert with Dr. Susan Perlman | January 2025
description:
Dr. Susan Perlman of UCLA Medical Center in Los Angeles joined us on January 8th, 2025, to answer the community's questions about Ataxia. The National Ataxia Foundation is proud to present this next installment in our Ask the Expert series.

To learn from other sessions with Dr. Perlman, visit www.ataxia.org/AsktheExpert

Ataxia is a rare neurological disease that can have a wide array of genetic origins. For more information on Ataxia, please visit our website: www.ataxia.org 

Become a Free NAF member! http://bit.ly/JoinNAF

Follow us on Social Media!
NAF Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/ataxiafounda... 
NAF Twitter:  https://twitter.com/NAF_Ataxia 
NAF Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ataxiafound... 
NAF Subreddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/ataxia/ 

About the Ataxia Expert:

Susan Perlman, MD is a graduate of Cornell University and the State University of New York at Stony Brook School of Medicine. She did an internship in medicine, her residency in neurology, and a two-year fellowship in Friedreich's Ataxia at UCLA Medical Center. Dr. Perlman is currently a Clinical Professor of Neurology and Director of the Ataxia Center at the UCLA Medical Center in Los Angeles, CA. She has been head of the Ataxia Center at UCLA since 1983. She has worked in Ataxia diagnosis for over 30 years and has networked with other â€œAtaxologistsâ€ across the country and around the world, trying to build better collaboration in the development to treatments and ultimately cures. She helped develop the National Ataxia Database for clinical research. She is participating in 2 natural history studies (for dominant Ataxia and Friedreichâ€™s Ataxia) and has participated in 7 clinical drug trials. Dr. Perlman would like to expand the work being done in non-genetic Ataxia as well. Dr. Perlman authored Evaluation and Management of Ataxic Disorders: An Overview for Physicians which has become a valuable resource for NAF.

title: CANVAS
description:
Canvas Syndrome Lecture

Introduction:
Canvas Syndrome, also known as Cerebellar Ataxia with Neuropathy and Vestibular Areflexia Syndrome (CANVAS), is a rare, progressive neurological disorder characterized by a triad of symptoms affecting balance, coordination, and sensory perception. This lecture will cover its clinical features, pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management.

1. Clinical Features:
 â€¢ Cerebellar Ataxia:
 â€¢ Involves impaired coordination of voluntary movements.
 â€¢ Symptoms include gait ataxia, difficulty with fine motor tasks, and tremors.
 â€¢ Neuropathy:
 â€¢ Peripheral sensory neuropathy, primarily affecting the sensory nerves.
 â€¢ Symptoms include numbness, tingling, and loss of sensation in the extremities.
 â€¢ Vestibular Areflexia:
 â€¢ Loss of vestibular function, leading to balance issues and dizziness.
 â€¢ Patients often report unsteadiness, especially in low-light conditions.

2. Pathophysiology:
 â€¢ CANVAS is considered a neurodegenerative disorder affecting the cerebellum, peripheral nerves, and vestibular system.
 â€¢ The exact cause is unknown, but genetic factors may play a role.
 â€¢ Recent studies suggest a potential link to mutations in the RFC1 (Replication Factor C Subunit 1) gene.

3. Diagnosis:
 â€¢ Clinical Evaluation:
 â€¢ Comprehensive neurological examination to assess ataxia, sensory loss, and vestibular function.
 â€¢ Electrophysiological Studies:
 â€¢ Nerve conduction studies (NCS) and electromyography (EMG) to evaluate peripheral neuropathy.
 â€¢ Vestibular Testing:
 â€¢ Video Head Impulse Test (vHIT) and caloric testing to assess vestibular function.
 â€¢ Imaging:
 â€¢ MRI of the brain to rule out other causes of ataxia and to assess cerebellar atrophy.
 â€¢ Genetic Testing:
 â€¢ Testing for RFC1 gene mutations if clinically indicated.

4. Differential Diagnosis:
 â€¢ Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)
 â€¢ Friedreichâ€™s Ataxia
 â€¢ Spinocerebellar Ataxia (SCA)
 â€¢ Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)

5. Management:
 â€¢ Symptomatic Treatment:
 â€¢ Physical therapy and rehabilitation to improve balance and coordination.
 â€¢ Vestibular rehabilitation exercises to help with dizziness and balance.
 â€¢ Supportive Care:
 â€¢ Occupational therapy for daily living adaptations.
 â€¢ Orthopedic interventions for neuropathic complications (e.g., foot drop).
 â€¢ Medications:
 â€¢ No disease-modifying treatments currently available.
 â€¢ Medications may be used to manage symptoms like neuropathic pain or tremors.

6. Prognosis:
 â€¢ CANVAS is a progressive condition, leading to gradual worsening of symptoms.
 â€¢ Life expectancy is typically not significantly reduced, but quality of life may be impacted.
 â€¢ Early diagnosis and management can help improve functional outcomes and reduce complications.

Conclusion:
Canvas Syndrome is a complex, multi-system disorder requiring a multidisciplinary approach for effective management. Ongoing research into its genetic basis and potential therapeutic targets holds promise for better future treatments.

References:
 â€¢ Recent studies on RFC1 mutations and CANVAS.
 â€¢ Clinical guidelines for the diagnosis and management of cerebellar ataxias.
 â€¢ Rehabilitation strategies for neurodegenerative disorders.

Feel free to ask any questions or request further details on specific aspects of CANVAS.

title: Here are some things people say to me having a rare disease, and my recommendations to respond!
description: Here are some things people say to me having a rare disease, and my recommendations to respond! #raredisease #friedreichsataxia #myastheniagravis #hemophilia #spinalmuscularatrophy #chroniccondition

title: Congenital neuromuscular disorders and anesthetic implications
description:
1. Pre-Junctional Disorders
- Charcot-Marie-Tooth: Peripheral denervation, avoid DNMBDs, prolonged NNMBD effects
- Friedreich Ataxia: Progressive ataxia, cardiac issues, avoid DNMBDs and negative inotropes

2. Post-Junctional Disorders
Dystrophies:
- Duchenne MD: Most common childhood type, dystrophin def
  - Avoid DNMBDs and volatiles (risk of rhabdomyolysis)
  - Reduce NNMBD dose, careful with reversal
  - Monitor for blood loss and maintain volume
Myotonias:
- Myotonic Dystrophy:
  - Features: Muscle wasting + incomplete relaxation
  - Avoid triggers (hypothermia, shivering)
  - Careful with NNMBD reversal
  - Watch for cardiac conduction issues
- Myotonia Congenita:
  - Most resistant to NNMBDs
  - Chloride channel dysfunction
  - Severe contractions can't be relaxed by NNMBDs
  - Consider sodium channel blockers for contractures
Periodic Paralysis:
- Hyperkalemic: Avoid potassium-releasing drugs, DNMBDs
- Hypokalemic: Associated with MH risk, monitor K+ levels

3. Metabolic/Mitochondrial Disorders
- Monitor metabolic status
- Avoid hypothermia
- May need glucose/amino acid infusion
- Watch for cardiac conduction issues
- Careful with local anesthetics and propofol

Key Management Principles:
1. Most conditions: Avoid DNMBDs
2. Monitor respiratory function
3. Watch for cardiac complications
4. Temperature management important
5. Careful dosing and reversal of NNMBDs when needed

title: The Outsiders: Patsy Spybey - John Pilger Documentary Interview - FULL FILM - Best Quality (1983)
description:
John Pilger Documentaries & Filmography: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLMV4WsADf_cKpptqKxqwkw1GIF9Or965w
All 9 Episodes of THE OUTSIDERS: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLMV4WsADf_cIt6APfDn3DKD8jSfgPN6Nz

1983. John Pilger interviews Patsy Spybey who sought treatment abroad when she was told there was no hope of recovery from a wasting disease. Despite criticism of her actions, she is now recovering.

Friedreich's ataxia (FRDA) is the name of the condition that Patsy Spybey suffered from, and I vaguely remember looking after some patients in a London hospital with that very debilitating condition. They suffered a lot. 

If you know how things went for Patsy, please leave a comment. It would be very interesting to find out. I hope she is doing ok. Interestingly, I have come across this news report, which, if this is the same person, suggests Spybey was still alive in 2001, but was suffering from cancer and wished to be discharged from hospital, due to multiple cancelled operations, and be allowed to 'die with dignity': https://www.thefreelibrary.com/%27LET+ME+DIE+IN+DIGNITY%27.-a077304234

RE; Video Copyright: John Pilger historically had a deal with UK television bosses, to allow his films be released into the public domain. True to his sentiment, I'm sharing this full film here, and will do so with many of his other most important films too. If you haven't watched any of his films before, they are a must watch. He is one of the - if not THE - greatest documentary filmmakers, and also journalists, of his generation!

RIP John Pilger, you are greatly missed!

title: 27INTERMIDIATE FILAMENT LAMIN CELL NUCLEUSHUTSHINSON GILFORD PROGERIA SYND HGPS  USMLE TYPE QUESTION
description:
CLUES FOR THE AMSWERS!!!!
(A) Duchenne muscular dystrophy â†’ Dystrophin mutation, presents with proximal muscle weakness, Gower's sign, and cardiomyopathy, but no premature aging.
(C) Myotonic dystrophy â†’ CTG repeat expansion, presents with myotonia, cataracts, and frontal balding.
(D) Xeroderma pigmentosum â†’ Defective nucleotide excision repair, causes UV sensitivity and skin cancers, but no lamin defects.
(E) Friedreich ataxia â†’ GAA repeat in frataxin gene, causes ataxia, cardiomyopathy, and scoliosis, but no progeria-like features.

title: Post 47 | Windows Into The Outside World.
description:
Welcome to The Wobbles Project, a mission inspired by my journey and driven by a simple yet profound belief: that empowerment and resilience can transform lives, no matter the challenges. Iâ€™m Andrew Marshall, and Iâ€™ve lived with Friedreichâ€™s Ataxiaâ€”a degenerative neuromuscular disorder that has profoundly shaped my life. Yet, my story is about more than this diagnosis. Itâ€™s about finding strength, joy, and purpose in sharing my experiences with others.

Through The Wobbles Project, Iâ€™m dedicated to creating a community where support, knowledge, and connection thrive. This initiative is an umbrella over various projects that all aim to make a meaningful impact for people with disabilities, beginning with accessible technology. For so many, devices like tablets open up a world of communication, learning, and independence. Itâ€™s my goal to provide this â€œwindow into the outside worldâ€ for those who might not otherwise have the chance.

The Wobbles Project encompasses my personal story, my YouTube channel, and a range of future projectsâ€”all united in the mission to empower and inspire.

Windows into the Outside World: This is my heart and the first branch to The Wobbles Project. Through this arm, I aim to provide technology to those in need, beginning with tablet donations to kids and adults with disabilities. Technology has been essential to my life, and itâ€™s my goal to pass along the empowerment it brings.

title: Dysdiadochokinesia #medicine #medicalstudent #clinicalmedicine #Dysdiadochokinesia #neetpreparation
description:
Dysdiadochokinesia (DDK) is a motor disorder characterized by an inability to perform rapid, alternating movements. It typically indicates cerebellar dysfunction. The condition is assessed by asking a person to perform tasks like rapidly flipping their hands or alternating between pronation and supination.

Causes:
 â€¢ Cerebellar lesions: Stroke, tumors, MS, or cerebellar atrophy.
 â€¢ Toxins: Alcohol, medications, and vitamin deficiencies (e.g., B12, thiamine).
 â€¢ Genetic disorders: Spinocerebellar ataxia, Friedreichâ€™s ataxia.
 â€¢ Trauma or infections: Head injury, encephalitis.

Diagnosis:
 â€¢ Clinical exam: Observing movement tasks like pronation-supination.
 â€¢ Imaging: MRI/CT to identify cerebellar damage.
 â€¢ Blood tests: For toxins or deficiencies.

Treatment:
 â€¢ Address underlying cause: Treat stroke, MS, or correct vitamin deficiencies.
 â€¢ Physical therapy: To improve coordination.
 â€¢ Discontinue toxins: Alcohol or drugs if involved.

title: Post 42 | Empowering Mobility: Portable Wheelchair Ramps
description:
In this video, we'll demonstrate how portable wheelchair ramps can significantly enhance the independence of individuals with mobility challenges, like Andrew who lives with Friedreich's Ataxia. We'll explore the ease and convenience of using these ramps for entering and exiting vehicles, as well as the cost-effectiveness compared to installing a permanent wheelchair lift.
Benefits of Portable Wheelchair Ramps:
â€¢ Easy to Use: Portable ramps are lightweight and fold compactly for easy storage and transportation. They can be quickly deployed and adjusted to accommodate various vehicle heights and wheelchair sizes.
â€¢ Versatility: These ramps are not limited to specific vehicles and can be used at home, work, or any location with step or height differences.
â€¢ Cost-Effective: Compared to installing a wheelchair lift, portable ramps offer a more affordable solution, making them accessible to a wider range of individuals.
â€¢ Maintains Vehicle Resale Value: Unlike permanent modifications, portable ramps can be removed without affecting the vehicle's resale value.
Demonstration:
We'll showcase the step-by-step process of using a portable wheelchair ramp to transfer Andrew and his wheelchair into a vehicle. This will include:
â€¢ Selecting the appropriate ramp size and type
â€¢ Positioning the ramp securely against the vehicle
â€¢ Safely manoeuvring the wheelchair onto the ramp
â€¢ Securing the wheelchair within the vehicle
Additional Considerations:
â€¢ Ramp length and slope are crucial for safe and comfortable transfers.
â€¢ Ramp materials should be durable and weather-resistant.
â€¢ Look for ramps with non-slip surfaces for added safety.

Portable wheelchair ramps provide a practical and affordable solution for individuals with mobility challenges, enabling them to maintain their independence and participate fully in everyday activities. By offering easy access to vehicles, these ramps empower individuals like Andrew to live more fulfilling lives.

If you or someone you know could benefit from a portable wheelchair ramp, consider exploring the various options available and discover how this simple solution can make a significant difference in their lives.

Note: Please ensure you follow all safety guidelines and instructions provided with your specific wheelchair ramp.

Advancing Rare Disease Research and Patient Advocacy | Notre Dame Stories
description:
In the United States, a disease must affect fewer than 200,000 people to be considered rare, but there are over 8,000 known rare diseases. That leaves the chances of being diagnosed with a rare disease in the U.S. at around 1 in 10, yet research and funding remain scarce. 

Rare diseases, commonly referred to as "orphan diseases," are often overlooked. As a result, effective treatments exist for less than 5% of all rare diseases, leaving millions of people without viable options.

Notre Dame is committed to understanding, treating, and advocating for those affected by rare diseases. This episode of Notre Dame Stories explores how researchers at the Boler-Parseghian Center for Rare Diseases are driving groundbreaking research to uncover new treatments and bring hope to patients and families.

Guests
  â€¢  Barb Calhoun, Reisenauer Family Director for Patient Advocacy Education and Outreach; Director of Minor in Science and Patient Advocacy
  â€¢  Sean Kassen, Director of the Ara Parseghian Medical Research Fund at the University of Notre Dame

-----
Video Chapters
00:00 Introduction: Fighting for those with rare diseases
04:57 Barb Calhoun shares her Notre Dame story
06:11 Barb discusses the benefits of rare disease research in a non-medical school
07:21 Barb talks about the Patient Advocacy Minor offered at Notre Dame.
09:07 Barb shares how the Patient Advocacy Program impacts students
11:57 Barb and Jenna share the inspiring story of a student with Friedreich's ataxia
16:24 What it means that Notre Dame is committed to patient advocacy
18:41 How Dean Santiago Schnell leads with compassion and serves as a role model to others
21:57 Sean Kassen shares his Notre Dame story
24:48 How the Boler-Parseghian Center for Rare Diseases came to be 
28:56 Sean shares his personal motivation for working with those with rare disease
29:54 How Notre Dame connects with families for rare disease research
33:12 Sean talks about recent and upcoming breakthroughs in rare disease research
35:04 Sean shares new Niemann-Pick Type C treatment options available
36:11 Sean tells us why rare disease research is so important to him

It was created by the Office of Public Affairs and Communications and hosted by Jenna Liberto with Executive Producer Andy Fuller. It was produced by Jenna Liberto, Josh Long, and Staci Stickovich. Videography was done by Zach Dudka, Josh Long, Tony Fuller, and Michael Wiens. Original music was provided by Alex Mansour. Listen and subscribe wherever you get your podcasts.

title: What Are Some Examples of Rare Diseases? | The Disease Encyclopedia
description:
What Are Some Examples of Rare Diseases? In this informative video, we will discuss some intriguing examples of rare diseases that impact many lives in unique ways. Rare diseases, by their nature, can often be overlooked or misunderstood, but they present distinct challenges for those affected. We'll introduce you to several conditions, each with its own characteristics and implications for health. From genetic disorders to rare cancers, these diseases can affect various systems in the body and manifest at different stages of life. 

Understanding these conditions not only raises awareness but also fosters compassion and support for those living with them. We will cover the symptoms, causes, and the impact these diseases have on daily life. If you are curious about the world of rare diseases and want to learn more, this video is for you. Join us as we uncover the complexity of these conditions and the stories behind them. Don't forget to subscribe to our channel for more informative content on diseases and medical conditions.

Based on the recommendation of several ABC employees, we decided to try Campo Bravo next.

Due to some nasty, ignorant comments regarding Natalie's disability, we have turned off comments for this video. Natalie has a MA in Arts in Medicine w/undergrad in psychology, a BA, as well as medical degree but has a neuromuscular disease similar to MS. This channel is about our family life, which includes many aspects of our life, our children, gardening, and Friedreich Ataxia (FA). Please check out our playlist on FA here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oXEvv8o3ZQ0&list=PLWZk8DFIJWYKBeVmhM1FISUQmpP95THcR&pp=gAQB

and her FA story right here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oXEvv8o3ZQ0&list=PLWZk8DFIJWYKBeVmhM1FISUQmpP95THcR

Before this nasty neurological disease took everything away from Natalie, she walked, ran, drove, lived on her own, and attended school on three separate college compasses, including the University of Florida, worked in the medical field, and worked at UF Health. Ignorant comments will be deleted, and hateful commenters will be deleted from our channel.

title: Medications & Diet for Ataxia (Day 1 AAC 2024)
description:
There are several medications and dietary changes that can be used to address symptoms caused by Ataxia. Dr. Rosenthal will review things that her patients have found helpful. Use these ideas to discuss options with your physician. 

Presented by Liana Rosenthal, MD, PhD

For more information on Ataxia, please visit our website: https://www.ataxia.org 

Become a Free NAF member! https://bit.ly/JoinNAF

Follow us on Social Media!
NAF Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/ataxiafounda... 
NAF Twitter:  https://twitter.com/NAF_Ataxia 
NAF Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ataxiafound... 
Ataxia Subreddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/ataxia/ 

As interest continues to grow from the pharmaceutical industry in developing drugs to treat Ataxia, we believe that collaboration among researchers, clinicians, pharmaceutical companies, and Ataxia patients is at a critical moment. Each of these groups must work together, as partners, to advance progress toward better patient care and more effective treatments for Ataxia. 2024 AAC was a place to connect, learn, and take action toward accelerating treatment development!

title: Post 49 | Chats with Gerda Brown from the Muscular Dystrophy Foundation of South Africa.
description:
Gerda Brown the director of operations at the Muscular Dystrophy Foundation South Africa and Andrew Marshall founder of The Wobbles Project are having a chat about the foundation and how they know each other as well as the projects they have collaborated on in the past. Andrew is also sharing some insights about The Wobbles Project and how he was inspired to begin with a brand-new leg of the project called Windows Into The Outside World.
Windows Into The Outside World was originally inspired by a colleague of Andrew's mom. They gave Andrew a computer which functioned as a window into the outside world for him. The computer became his lifeline when he needed to communicate with the outside world due to his Friedreichâ€™s Ataxia. Through this leg of the project, we hope we can empower people with technology.

title: What disabilities qualify for a service dog (under the ada)?
description:
Are you wondering what disabilities qualify for a service dog under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)? In this video, weâ€™ll break down exactly what the ADA says about service dog eligibility, including real-life examples of who would and wouldnâ€™t qualify.

ğŸ“Œ Topics Covered in This Video:
âœ… What the ADA defines as a disability for service dog qualification
âœ… Examples of individuals who would qualify for a service dog
âœ… Examples of individuals who wouldnâ€™t qualify
âœ… Why having both training records & medical documentation is important
âœ… The legal misconception about doctorsâ€™ notes & public access
âœ… The difference between service dogs, emotional support animals (ESAs), and therapy dogs

Reminders:
- A doctorâ€™s note is NOT required for public access, but having one before any legal issues arise can protect you.
- Service dogs MUST be task-trained to assist with a disability that significantly limits major life activities.
- Emotional support animals (ESAs) are NOT service dogs under federal law.
- Misusing service dog terms (ESA vs. therapy dog vs. service dog) can cause legal confusion, as well as general confusion for the public.

title: Ambulatory Facial Monitoring for Health with Dr Charles Nduka of Emteq Labs at the Buck Institute
description:
Dr Charles Nduka, surgeon and founder of Emteq Labs, introduces the concept of joyspan- the next metric beyond healthspan. Whereas lifespan measures the duration of life, and healthspan measures the duration of healthy years, joyspan measures the quantity of positive years. The rationale is that there is little point optimising healthspan if it leads to a worse quality of life.
In research, the quality of experiences is measured by assessing emotional valence. The most sensitive way to do this is via facial muscle activity, typically with facial electromyography. Charles Nduka invented facial optomyography as a non-contact alternative to allow passive, real-world monitoring of health, mood, dietary behaviours and neurological diseases.

By partnering with leading researchers, and health partners, Emteq Labs aims to make healthcare precise, predictive, proactive, participatory.
This talk was given at the Longevity Summit on 3rd December 2024 at the Buck Institute in California.

https://www.emteqlabs.com/
https://longevitygl.org/longevity-summit/

title: Deficiencia de aconitasa mitocondrial (mutaciones en ACO2)
description:
Deficiencia de Aconitasa Mitocondrial 

EpidemiologÃ­a

La deficiencia de aconitasa mitocondrial (ACO2) es un trastorno metabÃ³lico extremadamente raro, con solo unos pocos casos reportados en la literatura mÃ©dica. Se ha identificado en diversas poblaciones sin una distribuciÃ³n geogrÃ¡fica o Ã©tnica clara.

DescripciÃ³n clÃ­nica

La enfermedad se manifiesta principalmente con afectaciÃ³n neurolÃ³gica progresiva, incluyendo:
 â€¢ Retraso en el desarrollo psicomotor, con pÃ©rdida de habilidades adquiridas.
 â€¢ Ataxia cerebelosa, con dificultades en la coordinaciÃ³n y el equilibrio.
 â€¢ HipotonÃ­a y espasticidad, dependiendo de la progresiÃ³n de la enfermedad.
 â€¢ Discapacidad intelectual, de leve a severa.
 â€¢ DegeneraciÃ³n Ã³ptica y pÃ©rdida de la visiÃ³n en algunos casos.
 â€¢ En casos graves, se ha reportado neurodegeneraciÃ³n progresiva con hipoplasia cerebelosa.

EtiologÃ­a y genÃ©tica

La enfermedad es causada por mutaciones en el gen ACO2, ubicado en el cromosoma 22q13.2, que codifica la enzima aconitasa mitocondrial. Esta enzima es fundamental en el ciclo de Krebs, catalizando la conversiÃ³n del citrato en isocitrato. Su deficiencia provoca disfunciÃ³n mitocondrial, acumulaciÃ³n de citrato y alteraciones en el metabolismo energÃ©tico.

El patrÃ³n de herencia es autosÃ³mico recesivo, por lo que ambos padres deben ser portadores de una mutaciÃ³n para que su hijo herede la enfermedad.

MÃ©todos de diagnÃ³stico
 â€¢ Pruebas bioquÃ­micas:
 â€¢ DisminuciÃ³n de la actividad de aconitasa mitocondrial en fibroblastos o tejidos afectados.
 â€¢ AcumulaciÃ³n de citrato en plasma y orina.
 â€¢ Estudios genÃ©ticos:
 â€¢ IdentificaciÃ³n de mutaciones en el gen ACO2 mediante secuenciaciÃ³n molecular.
 â€¢ Neuroimagen (IRM cerebral):
 â€¢ Puede mostrar atrofia cerebelosa y signos de neurodegeneraciÃ³n progresiva.

DiagnÃ³stico diferencial

Debe diferenciarse de otros trastornos neurometabÃ³licos con afectaciÃ³n cerebelosa, tales como:
 â€¢ Enfermedades mitocondriales (mutaciones en genes como POLG o SURF1).
 â€¢ Ataxias hereditarias, incluyendo ataxia de Friedreich.
 â€¢ SÃ­ndromes neurodegenerativos con hipoplasia cerebelosa, como el sÃ­ndrome de Joubert.

Asesoramiento genÃ©tico

Dado que se hereda de manera autosÃ³mica recesiva, los padres de un niÃ±o afectado son portadores asintomÃ¡ticos. Se recomienda pruebas genÃ©ticas para familiares y diagnÃ³stico prenatal en embarazos con riesgo conocido.

Manejo y tratamiento

Actualmente, no existe un tratamiento curativo para la deficiencia de aconitasa mitocondrial. El manejo es sintomÃ¡tico y de soporte:
 â€¢ Fisioterapia y terapia ocupacional para mejorar la movilidad y el control motor.
 â€¢ Soporte nutricional, incluyendo dietas adaptadas a las necesidades metabÃ³licas del paciente.
 â€¢ Tratamiento sintomÃ¡tico para la espasticidad y la ataxia.
 â€¢ Monitoreo oftalmolÃ³gico y neurolÃ³gico regular.

PronÃ³stico

El pronÃ³stico varÃ­a segÃºn la gravedad de la enfermedad. En los casos mÃ¡s severos, la neurodegeneraciÃ³n progresiva puede llevar a una discapacidad grave y reducciÃ³n en la expectativa de vida. Sin embargo, en formas mÃ¡s leves, los pacientes pueden presentar una progresiÃ³n mÃ¡s lenta con manejo sintomÃ¡tico adecuado.

title: Treating Neuropathy With Laser Therapy
description:
Neuropathy can affect motor, sensory or autonomic nerve fibres separately or combined resulting in different symptoms. The onset of neuropathy can be acute or chronic and can affect all ages, however, some people are at greater risk with certain age-related diseases.  Among people older than 45 years, the prevalence of neuropathy is between 5-7%. Laser Therapy (photobiomodulation therapy or PBMT) when applied with optimal wavelengths, dosage and accurate location can accelerate nerve healing, increase circulation that supplies nerves, decrease pain and inflammation that may be associatyed with different types of neuropathies. J

oin BIOFLEXâ€™s Medical Director, Dr. David Kunashko for an in-depth review of the mechanisms of how PBMT can help neuropathies including peer reviewed research, optimal parameters, treatment plans and approaches using BIOFLEX professional Laser Therapy devices.
